comments.commentBody: W.A. Spitzer, you are correct. I watched the hearing today and heard what you heard.

Your hummus looks like it's been puréed, which makes the texture boring.  Instead, reserve 1/3 to 1/2 the chickpeas in Step 3 and roughly chop them in the food processor, adding them to the rest later, giving the whole a much more interesting texture and mouth-feel.

Wow, this is very loose, sticky dough. I made the recipe as written, and though the dough tasted salty (yes I tasted the dough) the bread itself was not overly salty. It had a lovely, crackery crust and airy interior. It was quite a challange getting it off the pizza peel onto the baking stone - the loaf rolled over itself and had a spiral of cornmeal inside, which added a nice bit of crunch to the bread. Use more cornmeal than you think you need! Very easy recipe, I will make it again.
My crust doesn't look at all like that pictured. Any suggestions? Thank you!
Easy trick let it rise on a piece of parchment paper on the peel side dough and paper onto stone.
I realized after I posted that I did reduce the salt by half, based on previous comments. I'm glad I did.
I used one lemon for the marinade and one to slice for the skillet. Two total. And no, I didn't squeeze any juice into the marinade. And yes, I did discard some juice from the skillet slices.

Your 1973 recipe is for 2 lbs of tomatoes which is 32 ounces vs this is  for 28 oz can of tomatoes. The onion halves are taken not to overwhelm the butter sauce..some have taken onions break them down and used them or toss them as this recipe says....fresh pasta works well with this or egg pasta too..enjoy
Do you have to peel the peaches or will the skins separate with cooking?

I love the scaring technique (though I haven't tried it). Best in my book is Harold McGee's method which yields more flavorful meat than simmering in water will. Since this dish doesn't require cooking the octopus in broth, McGee's method should be well suited to it.

http://www.nytimes.com/2008/03/05/dining/05curious.html?_r=0

I made a double batch of this chowder. It is delicious. I followed the recipe exactly but puréed about half and then added it back in, which helped the consistency enormously. The stock made from the corn cobs was great. I used whole milk. Great recipe and it doesn't need bacon.

Mayo and butter have oil bases, so either works fine for browning the bread.

I am partial to interesting flavors, so I use pumpernickel and smoked gouda. Melt the cheese open-face. Then I add a thick slice of beefsteak tomato before I fold the bread over. The gouda melts around the tomato, almost hiding it. My mouth is watering just typing this in. So good!

Great taste, had Napa cabbage that was almost over it's prime, did not have any dry sherry so used 1 TBS of Mirin and 1 TBS of Rice Vinegar.  Also used Red Pepper instead of Carrot.  Love the slightly spice flavor and a crunch still remains.  Will make again, perhaps finish with toasted sesame seeds.
I also added rice vinegar, even though I had dry sherry. The sherry didn't add enough flavor and this recipe needs a little zing and the rice vinegar really did the trick.

Made this tonight and it was a major hit. I used another crust recipe - mine's all butter, and uses 2.5 cups flour, so it works for a double-crust pie like this. This recipe, only calling for 2 cups flour, will be too little and you will be frustrated.

I tasted the peaches as I added the sugar in increments (my god, 1.25 cups seems excessive!), and ended up only using 1/2 cup. It was still EXTREMELY sweet (I had good peaches!) - but the lemon did a good job of mitigating some of that.

The summery bbq pork and succulent peach flavors together betray the ease of prep.  Excellent results prepared as written. I made this on an old Weber grill with a cast iron pan set atop the grill. It was 1.5 hr from butcher to table.
Agreed. To melt cheese perfectly covering with glass cover is the way to go. Makes it easier to reach perfection.
I am not apologizing for HRC, no need to apologize  , I am apologizing for our republicans to rest of the world .

Today, I watched four hours of the House Oversight & Government Reform Committee hearing with FBI Director Comey. The most amazing thing that I learned was that Hillary Clinton's testimony last Saturday was NOT taken under oath. It was a criminal investigation taking place over a year and occupying 30 thousand hours of a select FBI team that varied between 10 and 20 FBI agents. Also, FBI Director Comey did not attend the interview on Saturday and no transcript of the interview with Hillary Clinton was made.
Why would they require that (oath) from such a privileged person one rule for her and another for us.
Has James Webb ruled himself out (or otherwise been ruled out) as Trump's running-mate? If he'd accept, he'd be a formidable addition to the ticket. Gingrich or Pence are laughable by comparison.

Who cares whether or not Bernie speaks at the DNC convention?  I want Bernie to take the Democratic nomination and I have gone so far to ask him to not endorse Hillary Clinton.  Ms. Clinton was found to be "extremely careless" with our country's sensitive information by the FBI head.  That sends a strong no confidence message to me on her ability to perform the duties of the Presidency successfully.  I believe if Bernie Sanders expresses the same no confidence in Hillary Clinton then the American people will reward him with their vote for him come November. whether he runs on the Democratic ticket or not.  If you agree with me then why don't you go ahead and ask Bernie Sanders to not quit.  He CAN win the nomination.  It's up to YOU.

Dear Andrew:
Wake up to reality, it's over, or almost over. This long drawn out dance is about to conclude. Sanders will be on board, Hillary will be the nominee, and proceed to clean Trump's Clock Tower.

Hillary and Sander are two old pros whose experience has kept them both in the public office spotlight for decades. They did not get there by doing what you propose which is a do or die scenario. They will work out a win-win compromise that will unite the Democratic Party for the convention in Philly and then on to the General Election.

Hillary has been there done that. She is competent capable and has run one of the most professional campaigns in history. She is where she is out of determination and fortitude and a masterful approach at organization. It is why she will make an excellent president.

What you call for is not going to happen. Sanders is not crazy. He's a wily chess master who has played an excellent match, but he knows when to concede, and after getting all the concession he can. Your simplistic and naive notions are spoken in truly amateurish tones. Politics is not as you surmise like the pure driven snow. It's a lot of slush and mud. It's not a pretty sight and not for the fainthearted. That's why Hillary and Sanders are survivors.

DD
Manhattan

Politics involves the ability to give and take, to compromise when necessary, and during the process, act in an honorable fashion.

As the dust continues to settle from the Primaries and we see concessions from Hillary Clinton, I'd like to see Sanders do more than keep asking and start giving. I don't want much, but his voting AGAINST the Brady Bill and voting FOR the PLCAA-the Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act legislation that enables Gun Manufacturers and Gun Dealers from being sued) should be on the table, especially as we continue to witness the ever present 'gun violence' that exists in our country.

Sanders's defenders knee-jerk reaction to this criticism is how he gets a D- on the NRA's Report card. Well, let's make it an F by having him vote FOR The Brady Bill, legislation simply requiring a reasonable waiting period before the purchase of a firearm, and AGAINST the PLCAA-The Protection of Lawful Commerce in Arms Act, the act that protects Gun Manufacturers and Gun Dealers from being sued. And because half of Sanders's constituency are gun owners, this will not be an easy 'ask' of nor his complying with this request to climb from the bed of the NRA, the Gun Lobby, and Gun Manufacturers on these issues.

It is because of his reluctance to stand up to the NRA and the Gun Lobby on these issues that he lost the Democratic Nomination. His supporters are primarily students trying to get out from beneath their Student Loan Debt and gun owners. Result-he lost.
Thanks, JavaJunkie.  With freedom comes great responsibility.  Unfortunately, many believe that freedom really is free.  (Well, i guess for the 1%, it IS.)

@merc

The First Amendment was written at a time when there was no Radio or TV or telephones.
Should that mean you don't have the right to free speech on the TV or your cell phone?

So if you want strict interpretations then you should not be allowed to express your opinion on the internet via the NY Times website...

Vietnam ended when I was a child.
Would you now fault me for not serving in the Army or Marines when I was eight years old and therefor am not entitled to the same civil rights as you?
Thank you.  My cousin was a Marine in Vietnam, and he would absolutely agree with you.  He hunts with a bow and arrow, has never owned an AR15, and the old rifles are in a gun safe.

I'd say that Clinton has poisoned more of the Sanders voters than she has.  Who can trust her anymore?  Do you actually believe a word she says?  If so I've got some Florida swampland I'd like to sell you.

What is so striking about this incident and many of the others that have been captured over the years is that once the shooting takes place, zero effort is made to render medical assistance to the victim, or to check on their condition.  The police seem very ok with this being normal.  That to me, more than the shooting itself, affirms the notion that black lives don't matter.  In this incident, they seemed much more concerned with detaining the girlfriend, than determining what to do next for the victim.  How tragic for her, her daughter to humiliated so, while someone they cared for was murdered before their eyes.  What should be the take away of the little girl to see such a thing? It's a heart-breaking state of affairs that the United States is experiencing.
This has also happened in multiple shootings, in schools, etc.  The police refuse to let paramedics attend to the wounded for hours.

And why didn't the woman put pressure on the wound instead of attending to her Facebook broadcast? A man is dying from probably blood loss since the wounds were on his arm. She might have kept him alive (officer obviously could have done this, too, but that's not the point. The victim was her boyfriend, not a stranger.)
Please don't say the officer wouldn't let her. We'll never know. She never even asked.

Is this ever going to end? The "will-he-won't-he" final embrace before the next barage of poisoned arrows and poisoned comments coming from both sides of the aisle.
With each passing day, we seem to get further from the truth, and more involved in the running gag this Presidential election has become.
Clinton is no saint. Neither is Sanders. And it's probably too late to successfully float a third party candidate, even though it's a good idea.
It's high time to finally move on.
As the great Yogi said, "it ain't over 'til it's over."

@andrew
Or, until the fat lady sings......I'm still listening.
Other than the 18 minute gap, he was not given the opportunity to have his own lawyers review  the  tapes, and to edit out what they decided was "personal"

Why are the police in this country so out of control? I just don't get it. What is wrong with these policemen? Maybe they need psychological testing before they are allowed to do the job. No it's not an easy job but it's what they signed up for and that's not an excuse for shooting people in cold blood. Despicable.

If there is one apologia for police violence for which I have utterly lost any patience and which I do not want to hear in response to either the Minnesota or Baton Rouge shootings, it is the one that appeals to how hard a job being a police officer is.  Yes, it is difficult.  Nobody ever promised otherwise.  If you can't handle it, get another job.  Period.
